Comment: **TLDR:**  * **Trump's 10% baseline tariff on nearly all countries is not going anywhere, the White House says.** * **Since they were first announced on April 2, Trump's sweeping tariffs have disrupted markets and supply chains globally. Since then, Trump has made a number of changes to his tariff policies.** * **Earlier this week, Trump flatly said "no" when asked if he would consider lowering his tariffs on China. But on Friday, Trump appeared to contradict himself, suggesting in a Truth Social post that the Chinese tariff could be lowered to 80%.**

Comment: It's also going to hurt some groups who really wouldn't expect it.   A host of key raw inputs, partially prepared inputs, and some specialised machinery or bleeding edge technology America imports for manufacturing value added goods is going to become more expensive, making American manufacturing less efficient and cost effective. Half of what America manufactures it sells overseas, and those export products are going to be considerably less competitive on the global market.   When you increase the costs of things workers need to buy, you increase your labour costs. This further makes your products and services less competitive.   So some middle class trade and professional groups are going to be hit pretty hard by these tariffs.   The steel and aluminium tariffs in particular are going to be brutal for American automotive and aeronautic engineering. Boeing and Tesla were already struggling. These tariffs could be lethal.  And let's not even get into what the responding tariffs are going to do to a host of American sectors, especially agriculture, food and beverages.
